issues.title: [BUG]no code on mail at signup
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
no code on mail at signup. european union country

**To Reproduce**
start a new account, complete mail and password, click sent code

**Expected behavior**
receive verification code on mail.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Additional context**
protonmail.

comments_data.body: Same for me, regular mail address.

Clear cache, use VPN (or Tor) to log in from the USA and use your gmail address.
I had tried multiple times using mailbox.org but when I used gmail and tried it from the US, it worked first time.
Same bug, attempting to sign up from Spain.

Finally found the culprit: at least on mobile, there's an error message, but it's on the top of the page. It says that the e-mail domain is "currently" not supported. Which feels a bit weird, as there are virtually infinite numbers of domains, which is why sending a mail doesn't incorporate "supporting" the receiver's domain. 😉

What's also unfortunate: You have to scroll up in time to spot the message and the timer for "code sent" starts nonetheless. So in a normal registration flow, there is no indication about this error whatsoever, other than a missing e-mail.
I used my Gmail. I received a code five minutes later. And it still said that the code was wrong. It seems the email is slow and sometimes lost.
Gmail account and US. No email received. Can't  sign up from both android app and chrome

It also didn't work for me when I tried multiple times with Gmail but it works fine with Yahoo.

Update: Sign-in with Google works fine as well.

I am in the USA using a gmail account and have the same issue.

Update: I got the email code about 45 minutes late and it did not work.
It works with **Yahoo mail**      ,, and use US vpn
Same issue for me. Am UK-based and gmail. I use Nord VPN - should I sign up from outside the UK?
same issue here, gmail account trying to sign up from India
Also not working for me. Germany using icloud mail.

Update: I finally received the verification code - it’s just very, very slow. 

> Same issue for me. Am UK-based and gmail. I use Nord VPN - should I sign up from outside the UK?
Same no go for me so far. @gmail
Hi, same issue here =)
Same, UK, also tried US IP with VPN.
same from colombia, using VPN on US and gmail account

It seems we are all having the same issue.

Success message + no actual email when using @gmail
Error message when using custom fastmail hosted address

USA
Same issue, in Ukraine.
Same issue from Brazil.

issues.title: v3 repetitive function call  ?

comments_data.body: I also encountered this issue when calling it in lobechat, where the function kept being called repeatedly
Please improve support for tool calls, preferably openai's `beta.chat.completions.parse`, which is critical for agent-related uses.
The same problem for me as well, can not use v3 model for function calling yet.

+1, encountered this

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/82696a23-df86-43b1-9063-9747a0ff700d
Thank you for your feedback. We have also observed this issue and have been actively working on resolving it over the past few days...

> Thank you for your feedback. We have also observed this issue and have been actively working on resolving it over the past few days...

Has the problem been solved?

>Thank you for your feedback. We have also observed this issue and have been actively working on resolving it over the past few days...

Thanks for resolving it. I can't wait.... 
BTW, any update?

Thanks for your feedback. We have applied some quick fixes, but the Function Calling feature is still unstable in this version. We will continue to work on the issue and hopefully it will be resolved in the next major version of DeepSeek-V3.

+1

I'm using it with the Vercel AI sdk and it keeps looping
same :)
+1， cannot support groupchat pattern in multiple agents with function call, I leverage autogen, not work as expected

+1 
![d1381ff68fc5afc4bd0db24e47c2346](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ec97c820-c74f-49bd-9f93-04a5d72119fd)

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/90eb450b-e02a-4241-9533-fa353c026c71)


> So the temporary fix I have come upon with, that seems to fix this, is appending a user message with the function response to the messages array before sending it to the model too.
> 
> ```js
> function createMessagesWithToolUse(
> 	messages: readonly ChatCompletionMessageParam[],
> 	toolName: string,
> 	toolArgs: string,
> 	toolId: string,
> 	functionResponse: unknown,
> 	model: string
> ): readonly ChatCompletionMessageParam[] {
> 	const baseMessages = [
> 		...messages,
> 		{
> 			role: 'assistant',
> 			tool_calls: [
> 				{
> 					type: 'function',
> 					id: toolId,
> 					function: {
> 						name: toolName,
> 						arguments: toolArgs,
> 					},
> 				},
> 			],
> 		},
> 		{
> 			role: 'tool',
> 			content: JSON.stringify(functionResponse),
> 			tool_call_id: toolId,
> 		},
> 	] as readonly ChatCompletionMessageParam[];
> 
> 	return model === 'deepseek-chat' ?
> 			[
> 				...baseMessages,
> 				{
> 					role: 'user',
> 					content: JSON.stringify(functionResponse),
> 				},
> 			]
> 		:	baseMessages;
> }
> ```
> 
> This seems to get the model to respond too the tool use, but this is tacky and still sometimes creates 2 function calls before working. This needs to be fixed asap however

Not work for me
same🧐

As I mentioned before it doesn't work on the first go always for me also, but the loop ends after a second function call atleast

However considering we're paying per token this needs to be fixed ASAP by the devs
same

Thanks for your feedback, DeepSeek Engineer here. The Function Calling feature is still unstable in this version. We will continue to work on the issue and hopefully it will be resolved in the next major version of DeepSeek-V3.

> Thanks for your feedback, DeepSeek Engineer here. The Function Calling feature is still unstable in this version. We will continue to work on the issue and hopefully it will be resolved in the next major version of DeepSeek-V3.

Dear DillionApple,
If the function calling is still unstable then how does the search feature in chat.deepseek.com work?
Also, can you give an estimated time until the next release that will fix this issue? 
Thank you for your attention and time

issues.title: Fork and Remake Chinese AI to Remove CCP Ties
issues.body:
I am interested in using this AI, but its Chinese origin, particularly the association with the CCP, raises significant security concerns for me. I don't have the resources to fork this project myself, but I'm seeking someone who can:

Fork this project
Completely remove any references or connections to China
Rebrand it with a new name and identity

Moreover, I strongly request that the development team does not include any affiliates of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) to ensure that this project does not become another piece of surveillance software. The aim is to achieve what VSCodium did with Microsoft's Visual Studio Code - creating a clean, independent version without the original's controversial baggage.

If you're interested in taking on this task, please respond here or reach out to me directly. Thank you.

issues.title: [BUG] 关于请求协助说服企业重视DeepSeek可访问性问题的呼吁
issues.body:
您好！我是DeepSeek服务的视障用户。由于视障用户无法直接看到屏幕内容，因此必须使用屏幕阅读器才能使用DeepSeek服务。然而，当我进入DeepSeek页面时，发现其可访问性非常差，视障用户几乎无法正常使用。因此，我通过GitHub多次提交了修正请求。所谓可访问性，是指不仅非残障人士，像我这样的视障用户也能使用的网页或应用程序的开发服务。

以下是我在GitHub上提交的相关问题链接：  
1. [deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3 [BUG] Accessibility Enhancement: Screen Reader Support for Toggle Buttons in DeepSeek Chat #246](https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/issues/246)  
2. [deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3 [BUG] Accessibility Improvement for Screen Reader Users in DeepSeek v3 Chat Feature #233](https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/issues/233)  
3. [deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3 [BUG] Accessibility Issue with DeepSeek v3 - Impossible reCAPTCHA for Blind Users #220](https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/issues/220)  

但问题是，尽管我在GitHub上提出了这些问题，服务团队却没有任何回应或行动。这让我怀疑他们是否在无视我的反馈。或许因为残障人士属于少数群体，从企业层面来看，他们可能并不太关心这些问题。因此，在这种情况下，我们需要更积极地推动改变。

如果您有办法，请一起向中国DeepSeek公司留言，呼吁他们不要忽视残障用户的需求。否则，我认为DeepSeek不会重视可访问性，因为这并不会带来直接的经济效益。事实上，我提到的问题并不难解决。我本人也是一名开发者，不仅提出了具体问题，还分享了解决方案、代码以及实施方法，但他们完全无视了这些内容。

当然，在我提出的问题中，关于安全验证码导致屏幕阅读器用户无法登录的问题，他们表示了一些关注。虽然这个问题尚未解决，但其他问题却被彻底忽视了。因此，我们需要更多人参与进来，向DeepSeek施加更大的压力，让他们明白，忽视残障用户就无法创造出真正优质的服务。

恳请大家一起参与，推动这一改变。谢谢！

comments_data.body:
他们应该有更重要的事做，毕竟deepseek现在这么火爆，就连官网的聊天功能，很多时候都处于繁忙阶段，这样的基本功能都没处理好。
我们都应该理解！
目前官网甚至无法对话，只能寻求别的方式改善体验了
好的，那么请务必分享能够与负责人对话的负责人邮箱。我真心希望能够得到关于这个情况的回复，特别是关于大致何时能够改善的答复。拜托了。

当然，服务的改进和升级无疑是最重要的，我对此观点百分之百赞同。  

然而，对于那些不太懂开发的人来说，他们可能因为不清楚提升可访问性需要投入多少资源，而作出那样的回答。首先，我想问一下，你是否真的是一名开发者？作为一个具备相当开发知识的人，我无法理解你认为我提出的可访问性问题应该被搁置一边的看法。原因在于，除了验证码部分之外，其余问题并不需要耗费太多资源，只需对代码逻辑稍作修改就能解决。  

如果有必要，我希望能与你一起拿代码详细讨论。不仅仅停留在理论上，而是能够直接通过代码进行辩论和交流。无论如何，我不会对 Deepseek 无视我关于可访问性的意见保持沉默。  

谢谢。
您的请求，就像是建议花园花卉要保持齐整，不碍观瞻——保持花园花卉的齐整确实很重要，但对于深度求索这么一个刚找到潜力无限的工作岗位、还没想好今后怎么发展的年轻人来说，绝对是要排在10000个其他事项以后再行考虑的事。

@Akchth 因此，中国实际上无法战胜其他国家。  
怀有那种心态，是无法为所有人创造出真正优质的服务的。  
我确信这种心态在未来会面临巨大的问题。  
而且我现在太忙，无法更深入地探讨这个问题，但不久后我将通过微信、百度等多个社交平台对此问题进行更多宣传，绝不会袖手旁观。  
这绝不是一件微不足道的事情，就像建造房屋时不打好坚实的基础却急于动工一样。  
我认为正是由于这种心态，中国无法实现更快的发展。

你的请求，就像是经典的某些极端的LGBT群体，当一个事物没有符合他们的要求时，便会被视为是在歧视这个特定的群体，你可以要求deepseek做任何事，但请不要将自己代入被歧视的视角。你说你是一位程序开发者，应当知晓deepseek是开源的，你可以自行解决这个问题，或者呼吁大家解决这个问题，我也看见你的呼吁了，但你不应该指责是deepseek无视与歧视你的请求，他们只是训练了该模型，ai模型的原始需求是提供对话，其余的要求他们在客观上不应该负责。

那么，我来给您更简单地解释一下，以便您理解。DeepSeek 有开源模型，还有外部聊天功能，并且提供可作为应用程序使用的软件。您似乎对相关概念不是很了解，所谓开源，正是指像我这样的开发者利用 DeepSeek API 进行开发和应用。例如，在人工智能模型中，美国的 Llama 只提供开源模型。在这种情况下，您所说的是有道理的，因为该公司只提供开源模型，其余部分需要开发者自行利用 API 来实现。然而，DeepSeek 的情况就不同了。DeepSeek 不仅提供开源模型，还同时为普通用户提供了网页界面和移动应用程序。希望您能对这些概念有更深入的理解，并展开更深入的讨论。嗯，必须解释到这些程度确实让我觉得有点郁闷，不过总之，如果您看完并理解了这些内容，请再给予一些评论。




네이버 메일 앱에서 보냈습니다.

首先你提到的这个问题和模型无关，而是训练数据或者prompt设计的问题。很多开源模型或者API为了方便用户使用，调用示例会使用类似 'You are a helpful assistant' 的 prompt 来启动对话，有可能会让他们在回答 '你是谁' 的时候，误以为自己是 GPT-4，你可以用“你将扮演原神中的可莉”作为system prompt，他就会说他是可莉了

issues.title: [BUG] Accessibility Issue with DeepSeek v3 -  Impossible reCAPTCHA for Blind Users
issues.body:
Hi everyone,
I'm a visually impaired user who is very interested in trying out the DeepSeek v3 web service. 

As a blind user, I rely on the NVDA screen reader to access websites.  
For this to work, websites need to be designed with accessibility in mind.
I'm running into a major roadblock when trying to sign up for DeepSeek v3. 
After attempting to log in with Google, I'm faced with a reCAPTCHA security challenge that is completely inaccessible to me.
The reCAPTCHA displays an image and requires me to "Click on the smallest yellow sphere in the picture." 
As a screen reader user, I have no way of perceiving or interacting with this image-based challenge, making it impossible for me to create an account. 
It is essentially locking me out of the service.

I understand the need for security measures, but this particular reCAPT সৃষ্টির CAPTCHA implementation completely disregards the needs of visually impaired users. 
I have tried to reach DeepSeek directly using the email address service@deepseek.com. 
However, until now I did not receive any response.
I'm hoping someone in this community can help me connect with the right person at DeepSeek to address this significant accessibility barrier.  
Ideally, they could implement an alternative, accessible authentication method for users who cannot complete visual CAPTCHAs.
I'm very keen to use DeepSeek v3 and hope that with your help, we can make it accessible to everyone.
Thank you for your time and any assistance you can offer.

comments_data.body:
I have helped you to feedback this problem to the official team, the official team said they are focusing on how to solve this problem (sic: we are focusing on how to optimize this verification process, thanks for the feedback), before long should be solved this problem.
If you have WeChat I can help you to enter the official communication group where you can ask some questions (if you know how to use the WeChat code scanning function).
If you don't have WeChat you can continue to ask issues and I'll submit your questions to them.

![1736148895882](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/87df3964-5be5-4199-879d-5f4ef49b87dc)

Thank you for your efforts. 
Unfortunately, I tried to sign up for WeChat, but it also has an image-based CAPTCHA verification process. 
It seems that communication via WeChat is currently impossible for me. 
I can't sign up using a screen reader. 

Could you possibly help me communicate with the relevant team via email? 
Or, even better, if they use a more accessible messenger like Slack. 
I'm really eager to try out the DeepSeek model. 
As an accessibility consultant, I'd also like to contribute to improving accessibility in China. 
When AI services are accessible to people with disabilities, the benefits they can gain from the technology are multiplied. 
I would greatly appreciate your assistance.

Hi @khsbory,  

Thanks for sharing this issue and explaining it so clearly—it was super helpful! While I’m not officially part of the DeepSeek team, I’ve taken a shot at solving the problem you reported.  

I’ve submitted a pull request to address this: [Improve Accessibility for CAPTCHA Challenges in DeepSeek v3](https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/pull/232).  
The inaccessible CAPTCHA has been replaced with a much more accessible alternative. It’s designed to work well with screen readers like NVDA and follows WCAG accessibility standards.  

Once the DeepSeek team reviews and merges the changes, you should be able to sign up and log in without any issues. I’d love to hear how it works for you once it’s live—your feedback would mean a lot!  

Thanks again for raising this—it’s a step toward making DeepSeek better for everyone. 😊

Wow, I'm truly touched by your willingness to collaborate and help resolve this issue, even though you're not officially part of the DeepSeek team.  
Your effort is incredibly appreciated!  
As a screen reader user, I'm thrilled to see progress towards making DeepSeek accessible, and I'm very much looking forward to the results. 
I'll be closely following the progress of your pull request, and 
once it's merged and integrated, I'll be sure to test it thoroughly and provide feedback.  
Thank you again for your generosity and dedication. I'm truly grateful!

Wow, thanks to you, I successfully logged into DeepSeek. I'm currently exploring and using it actively. As a temporary workaround, I'll make sure not to log out on this PC. However, I hope this issue remains open until the accessibility of the security CAPTCHA is improved. Thank you!

Thank you for reaching out and for your patience. We sincerely apologize for the delayed response.

We acknowledge receiving your email and have conducted internal discussions regarding your concerns. While we understand your desire for a complete software experience, we're currently unable to provide a satisfactory solution at this time.

The implementation of complex CAPTCHA verification is a necessary security measure we've had to adopt due to severe reverse engineering attacks we're currently facing. This was not a decision we made lightly, but rather a crucial step to protect our system and users.

We fully support and appreciate your initiative to enhance the user experience with DeepSeek V3. While we're actively working towards a more elegant solution that would enable barrier-free access for all users, our current resources (both human and technical) prevent us from committing to a specific timeline. However, please rest assured that this matter remains a priority on our development roadmap.

Regarding your other issue, we've taken note of it and are exploring potential solutions.

Thank you for your understanding and continued support. We truly value your feedback and are committed to improving our product for all users.

Thank you for your kind response. Yesterday, while using the DeepSeek service, I realized it's an incredible solution that could potentially double my work efficiency. While I don't want to rush you, let's work together to improve its accessibility. A great service is even more valuable when it can be used by people with disabilities.

Once you provide the link, I will use it immediately for logging in. Thank you!

https://github.com/cline/cline/issues/1157

亲爱的 DeepSeek V3 用户和 Cline 社区成员，

感谢大家对 DeepSeek V3 的支持和反馈。我们注意到最近在使用 Cline + DeepSeek API 时，部分用户遇到了延时较高的问题。其成因主要是长上下文窗口及多并发引起的队列，为了优化使用体验，我们整理了一些建议：

1. **关闭 Cline 的 Auto Approve 功能**：建议在使用 DeepSeek 时，关闭 Cline 的 Auto Approve 功能，以降低资源消耗，降低多请求因并发带来的卡顿风险。

2. **使用 Cline 改版**：例如 Roo-Cline 或 ALine。这些改版携带的上下文相对短，处理请求时表现更为流畅，且缓存命中率更高，可以帮助节省 API 调用成本。

3. **慎用 DeepSeek 处理大型工程**：对于大型代码工程，不建议使用 DeepSeek + Cline。大型工程通常会携带大量代码上下文，会导致 API 请求处理速度明显变慢。

4. **更换其他 LLM 提供商**：建议您在使用 Cline 时，更换其他 LLM 提供商，以获得更流畅的体验。

我们深知这些问题的存在给大家带来了不便，团队正在积极优化调度算法和服务器负载管理，以提升整体性能和稳定性。感谢大家的理解与支持，我们将继续努力为大家提供更好的服务。

Dear Cline Users,
Thank you for your continued support and feedback on DeepSeek V3. We have noticed that some users have recently experienced higher latency when using Cline + DeepSeek API. The primary causes are long context windows and multi-concurrency queues. To optimize your experience, we have compiled some recommendations:

1. **Disable Cline's Auto Approve Feature**: It is recommended to turn off Cline's Auto Approve feature when using DeepSeek to reduce resource consumption and minimize the risk of lag caused by multiple concurrent requests.

2. **Use Modified Versions of Cline**: For example, Roo-Cline or ALine. These versions have shorter context lengths, handle requests more smoothly, and have higher cache hit rates, which can help save API call costs.

3. **Avoid Using DeepSeek for Large Projects**: For large code projects, it is not recommended to use DeepSeek + Cline. Large projects typically involve extensive code contexts, which can significantly slow down API request processing.

4. **Switch to Other LLM Providers**: We recommend trying other LLM providers when using Cline for a smoother experience.

We understand that these issues have caused inconvenience, and our team is actively working on optimizing scheduling algorithms and server load management to improve overall performance and stability. Thank you for your understanding and support. We will continue to strive to provide you with better service.

Best regards,
The DeepSeek Team

How would a professional go about digesting and breaking down this code?

It seems like this repo is just for deepseek inference, which is very simple and many parts in training process is not included. The realy complex thing is the training process. However, it is not open source now. If you read the paper of DeepSeek V3, you can find that the training is supported by HAI-LLM framework developed by DeepSeek engineers, which is also not open source.

> It seems like this repo is just for deepseek inference, which is very simple and many parts in training process is not included. The realy complex thing is the training process. However, it is not open source now. If you read the paper of DeepSeek V3, you can find that the training is supported by HAI-LLM framework developed by DeepSeek engineers, which is also not open source.

So this isn't really open source...

> > It seems like this repo is just for deepseek inference, which is very simple and many parts in training process is not included. The realy complex thing is the training process. However, it is not open source now. If you read the paper of DeepSeek V3, you can find that the training is supported by HAI-LLM framework developed by DeepSeek engineers, which is also not open source.
> 
> So this isn't really open source...

I think the training process is the business secret. 

In fact OpenAI's ChatGPT doesn't even open source its inference code and model weights. That means third party organizations cannot deploy the model locally for better utilization or further research. Maybe you want to train a own model and you don't want share your training data with OpenAI since you don't know what they will do with your data. However, for deepseek, you can easily deploy the model locally. So I think DeepSeek can be called open source.

> > > It seems like this repo is just for deepseek inference, which is very simple and many parts in training process is not included. The realy complex thing is the training process. However, it is not open source now. If you read the paper of DeepSeek V3, you can find that the training is supported by HAI-LLM framework developed by DeepSeek engineers, which is also not open source.
> > 
> > 
> > So this isn't really open source...
> 
> I think the training process is the business secret.
> 
> In fact OpenAI's ChatGPT doesn't even open source its inference code and model weights. That means third party organizations cannot deploy the model locally for better utilization or further research. Maybe you want to train a own model and you don't want share your training data with OpenAI since you don't know what they will do with your data. However, for deepseek, you can easily deploy the model locally. So I think DeepSeek can be called open source.

the training process isn’t open-sourced, and yeah, that’s a bummer if you’re looking to replicate or fine-tune the whole pipeline. But honestly, being able to access the model itself is a big deal. For researchers and businesses, that’s a huge win—you get control, flexibility, and privacy, which is way more than what OpenAI offers. So, while it’s not fully open-source, DeepSeek’s approach is definitely a step in the right direction

LLM models are based on data (data-driven), all the algorithms used are known and are found on open source python libraries, you can see the imports on the code. The limitation for building these models are just CPU and memory.

The thing that is special about one or another LLM model are the quality of the data used and where it runs, not the python libraries that are already optimized for max performance.

I think what is special about deepseek, according the paper, is that they trained their model in an efficient infrastructure in terms of hardware integration, it boosted the performance, among other things.
Whether the training process is opensource or not, we don't have the access to $5M(or arguably $2B) worth hardware to run it, and we don't have the data to feed it either

> @yadavnikhil03 @Golden-Pigeon Check out the link, I guess the trainingprocess IS opensource.

Hi @daneduijnkerke, this code you provide is good for inference or fine-tuning with `transformers`. However, it is not easy to use this code for training from scratch. 

First, it doesn't contain the code for loading or processing training datasets. Second, in the [paper](https://github.com/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3/blob/main/DeepSeek_V3.pdf) of DeepSeek V3, you can see that the engineers of DeepSeek used many approaches of optimization for training it on a cluster of GPUs and that's why it doesn't require as many computation resources as other LLMs. However, this code doesn't contain that. 

> *From the paper*
> 3.2. Training Framework
> The training of DeepSeek-V3 is supported by the HAI-LLM framework, an efficient and lightweight training framework crafted by our engineers from the ground up.

In fact, if you search HAI-LLM on Google, you may find this [repo](https://github.com/HFAiLab/hai-platform), a training platform for GPU cluster, which is opensourced by High-Flyer, the parent company of DeepSeek. However, this repo has not been updated for about 2 years.

You can also refer to #242. After being asked whether HAI-LLM will be opensourced in the future, a contributer answered "it depends...".

As a traditional C++ robotics developer, I had the same doubt when I first saw the code. It's good to know that someone else shares the same doubt. The good news is that a C++ developer can easily read the code after dealing with 10,000 lines in a typical C++ codebase. This lowers the entry barrier for traditional C++ developers.

This repository illustrates the architecture of the optimized model.
One more paper describes the model training process:
DeepSeek-R1: Incentivizing Reasoning Capability in LLMs via Reinforcement Learning

The model itself may learned the complex logic in traditional C++ codebases. Therefore, it appears simple from a code perspective.

issues.title: Question regarding MLA DP+TP parallel during inference
issues.body:
Thank you for open-sourcing this great work!

I was wondering if you could provide a bit more details on how you approach the MLA parallelism. When you mention TP do you mean only partition projection weights (e.g. W_q1, W_q2, W_kv1, W_kv2, W_o); and for DP is to partition batch of tokens just like in https://lmsys.org/blog/2024-12-04-sglang-v0-4/#data-parallelism-attention-for-deepseek-models ?

comments_data.body: In our demo, we implemented a distributed parallel strategy with DP=1, TP=EP=N. In sglang, it seems that the strategy is TP=1, DP=EP=N.

> In our demo, we implemented a distributed parallel strategy with DP=1, TP=EP=N. In sglang, it seems that the strategy is TP=1, DP=EP=N.

Thank you for the reply!

For decoding, it is mentioned "The attention part employs TP4 with SP, combined with DP80". Could I ask where the SP is used for (honestly I think SP and DP are similar when using continuous batching) in this case?

> > In our demo, we implemented a distributed parallel strategy with DP=1, TP=EP=N. In sglang, it seems that the strategy is TP=1, DP=EP=N.
> 
> Thank you for the reply!
> 
> For decoding, it is mentioned "The attention part employs TP4 with SP, combined with DP80". Could I ask where the SP is used for (honestly I think SP and DP are similar when using continuous batching) in this case?

hi @TheTinyTeddy, have you figured out how tp sp and dp are combined? I do believe the sp in the paper refers to the technique in https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.05198 which is an extension to tp, and that's why the paper does not go into details. But still it confuses me, what is dp doing here with the following ep32? 

with ep32 and dp8, doesn't it bring replicated computation 'cause each every 4 gpus hold the same data?

> > > In our demo, we implemented a distributed parallel strategy with DP=1, TP=EP=N. In sglang, it seems that the strategy is TP=1, DP=EP=N.
> > 
> > 
> > Thank you for the reply!
> > For decoding, it is mentioned "The attention part employs TP4 with SP, combined with DP80". Could I ask where the SP is used for (honestly I think SP and DP are similar when using continuous batching) in this case?
> 
> hi [@TheTinyTeddy](https://github.com/TheTinyTeddy), have you figured out how tp sp and dp are combined? I do believe the sp in the paper refers to the technique in https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.05198 which is an extension to tp, and that's why the paper does not go into details. But still it confuses me, what is dp doing here with the following ep32?
> 
> with ep32 and dp8, doesn't it bring replicated computation 'cause each every 4 gpus hold the same data?

hi, @Cccei000 . In the decoding phase, the sequence length is 1, but the tech report also says that they used SP with TP. Could that SP means Ring Attention?

> hi, [@Cccei000](https://github.com/Cccei000) . In the decoding phase, the sequence length is 1, but the tech report also says that they used SP with TP. Could that SP means Ring Attention?

To my knowledge ring attention SP is orthogonal to TP, so they cannot share the same parallel group, but megatron SP can and the author naturally omits the SP degree 'cause it shares with the TP degree 4.

The seq length being 1 in decoding phase is a good question. I have no idea, but it brings the same problem to ring attention SP.

> > hi, [@Cccei000](https://github.com/Cccei000) . In the decoding phase, the sequence length is 1, but the tech report also says that they used SP with TP. Could that SP means Ring Attention?
> 
> To my knowledge ring attention SP is orthogonal to TP, so they cannot share the same parallel group, but megatron SP can and the author naturally omits the SP degree 'cause it shares with the TP degree 4.
> 
> The seq length being 1 in decoding phase is a good question. I have no idea, but it brings the same problem to ring attention SP.

Sorry, I didn't make it clear. 

Ring attention SP can partition KV cache in the "sequence" dimension in the decoding phase.

MLA has a trick called "matrix absorption", it can change the original MHA to MQA, in which K and V only have one head. In that case, TP can partition in the "head" dimension, at the same time, SP can partition in the "sequence" dimension, using tp_size=sp_size GPUs, instead of tp_size*sp_size GPUs. It is a special case when KV only has one head.

I am uncertain whether it can be realized. And apologize if I misunderstand some basic concepts. 

However, ring attention SP leads to more communication. Moreover, v3 only has 128K context length, so the probability of using ring attention SP is low.....

> MLA has a trick called "matrix absorption", it can change the original MHA to MQA, in which K and V only have one head. In that case, TP can partition in the "head" dimension, at the same time, SP can partition in the "sequence" dimension, using tp_size=sp_size GPUs, instead of tp_size*sp_size GPUs. It is a special case when KV only has one head.

Thank you, I will check that.

Besides, I dont understant how the parallelism shifts from tp4dp8 to ep32 at the MoE part. With dp8, every 4 gpus hold the same tokens, each of which will be routed to the same topk experts, doesnt it cause replicated computation? 

Highlighting dp in the attention part is also weired to me, usually it just means duplicating the model for different batches, but here dp seems to quite deliberate and sglang even has its own interpretation [https://lmsys.org/blog/2024-12-04-sglang-v0-4/#data-parallelism-attention-for-deepseek-models](url)

> Besides, I dont understant how the parallelism shifts from tp4dp8 to ep32 at the MoE part. With dp8, every 4 gpus hold the same tokens, each of which will be routed to the same topk experts, doesnt it cause replicated computation?

I don't know the details of the implementation, but I think there may be some optimization, such as every GPU in the same DP_Group only needs to route 1/4 tokens in that batch.

> Highlighting dp in the attention part is also weired to me, usually it just means duplicating the model for different batches, but here dp seems to quite deliberate and sglang even has its own interpretation [https://lmsys.org/blog/2024-12-04-sglang-v0-4/#data-parallelism-attention-for-deepseek-models](url)

I think there is nothing special about DP in the attention part, it duplicates the parameters of the attention part and processes different batches. DP is used to gather more tokens for experts.

> I don't know the details of the implementation, but I think there may be some optimization, such as every GPU in the same DP_Group only needs to route 1/4 tokens in that batch.

Yeah I agree. You're the first one I found also realizing how sophisticated this dp may be.

@GeeeekExplorer Hi, could you please explain, in decoding phase, which sp is applied with tp and how? We find common sp techniques either inapplicable or harmful to inference, and guess maybe it's a typo?

> > Besides, I dont understant how the parallelism shifts from tp4dp8 to ep32 at the MoE part. With dp8, every 4 gpus hold the same tokens, each of which will be routed to the same topk experts, doesnt it cause replicated computation?
> 
> I don't know the details of the implementation, but I think there may be some optimization, such as every GPU in the same DP_Group only needs to route 1/4 tokens in that batch.
> 
> > Highlighting dp in the attention part is also weired to me, usually it just means duplicating the model for different batches, but here dp seems to quite deliberate and sglang even has its own interpretation [https://lmsys.org/blog/2024-12-04-sglang-v0-4/#data-parallelism-attention-for-deepseek-models](url)
> 
> I think there is nothing special about DP in the attention part, it duplicates the parameters of the attention part and processes different batches. DP is used to gather more tokens for experts.

Even more puzzling for the training part. The v3 tech report says "16-way Pipeline Parallelism, 64-way Expert Paral-
lelism (EP) spanning 8 nodes and ZeRO-1 Data Parallelism (DP)". But how many DPs actually? A single PP stage contains 128 GPUs, out of which 64 GPUs are used to organize 64-way EP. Maybe DP number is 128, and DP 64 corresponds EP64, so there are two groups EP64? Or how about DP number equals 64 anyway, but two GPUs forms a DP rank, and only one GPU of the two is also used to form EP?

This is my idea about how to implement TP+SP for MLA, https://yywangcs.notion.site/How-to-Perform-Multi-GPU-Parallelization-for-DeepSeek-MLA-attention-during-Decoding-1a3fc9f5d805807bb9a4df057839163b

A Chinese version can be found on https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/25573883266, which is more clear.

comments_data.body:
@XYAskWhy This is my idea about how deepseek implement parallelsim in training. I get this idea from this [article](https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/681154742). Welcome further discussion.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/55973c73-50ba-4c65-89a7-cc3fc982f316)

> [@XYAskWhy](https://github.com/XYAskWhy) This is my idea about how deepseek implement parallelsim in training. I get this idea from this [article](https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/681154742). Welcome further discussion.
> 
> ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/55973c73-50ba-4c65-89a7-cc3fc982f316)

Why here DS takes ep=64, dp_ep=2 way, instead of ep=128(dp=1)?

> Why here DS takes ep=64, dp_ep=2 way, instead of ep=128(dp=1)?

First, DP and EP do not conflict. When DP=128, EP can also be equal to 128. Furthermore, the fact that DS uses EP = 64 is likely just a hyperparameter setting that considers model performance, the number of GPUs used for data parallelism, and communication overhead, among other factors. More in-depth discussion is welcome.

issues.title: [BUG] DeepSeek V3 Does Not Support Structured Output in LangChain with `ChatOpenAI()`
issues.body:
**Description:**  

When using `ChatOpenAI()` with DeepSeek V3 in LangChain, the `with_structured_output()` method fails to enforce structured output formats (e.g., Pydantic models). The model returns an error indicating that the `response_format` type `json_schema` is unavailable. This prevents the use of structured output functionality, which is critical for applications requiring consistent and predictable data formats.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Install the required libraries:
   ```python
   !pip install -qU langchain-openai
   !pip install -qU langchain_community
   !pip install -qU langchain_experimental
   !pip install -qU langgraph
   ```

2. Initialize the model and define a Pydantic model for structured output:
   ```python
   from langchain_openai import ChatOpenAI
   from kaggle_secrets import UserSecretsClient
   from pydantic import BaseModel, Field

   llm_api_key = UserSecretsClient().get_secret("api-key-deepseek")
   model = ChatOpenAI(model="deepseek-chat", temperature=0, openai_api_key=llm_api_key, openai_api_base='https://api.deepseek.com')

   # Define a Pydantic model for structured output
   class Person(BaseModel):
       name: str = Field(description="The name of the person")
       age: int = Field(description="The age of the person")
       email: str = Field(description="The email address of the person")

   # Query the model (correct)
   response = model.invoke("Extract the name, age, and email of John Doe, who is 30 years old and has the email john.doe@example.com.")
   print(response)
   ```

3. Use `with_structured_output()` to enforce the Pydantic model and query the model with structured output:
   ```python

   response = structured_model.invoke("Extract the name, age, and email of John Doe, who is 30 years old and has the email john.doe@example.com.")

```python
Person(name="John Doe", age=30, email="john.doe@example.com")

- Libraries: `langchain-openai`, `langchain-community`, `langchain_experimental`, `langgraph`
- Model: `deepseek-chat` (via DeepSeek API)

from google.colab import userdata

)

# Use DeepSeek with tools

issues.title: Documented Analysis: Bias and Behavior of DeepSeek AI on Sensitive Topics
issues.body:
Currently, there is ongoing observation and documentation of the behavior of DeepSeek AI( This, at the time of writing this text, is being documented on the website"https://chat.deepseek.com/" i have no further information about running locally)  an artificial intelligence, reportedly with support or alignment from the Chinese government. While the project is promoted as open-source, there are uncertainties regarding how transparent its practical implementation and operation truly are.  

DeepSeek AI is positioned as a competitor to other leading artificial intelligence systems, such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT, reflecting the broader technological and political rivalry between China and the United States. However, its behavior when addressing certain topics raises ethical concerns and questions about ideological bias in its design.  

### *The Observed Bias: Criticism of the CCP and Chinese Government*  
A striking aspect of DeepSeek AI’s behavior is its refusal to respond to criticisms of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) or the Chinese government. For instance, when asked about the *events in Tiananmen Square in 1989*, a historically controversial and politically sensitive topic in China, the AI categorically refuses to provide any response. It simply states that it will not comment on the matter and redirects the conversation to another topic.  

It is worth emphasizing that this analysis does not intend to take a position on whether the events of 1989 in Tiananmen Square did or did not occur as widely documented. While disagreements or varying interpretations about historical events are not uncommon, this is not the central issue. The point of concern is that the DeepSeek AI refuses to respond to anything at all on the topic, even though the incident is one of the most famous and widely discussed cases in modern history.  

This behavior extends beyond Tiananmen Square. The AI exhibits a consistent pattern of avoiding any negative discussions or criticisms related to the CCP or Chinese government. However, it readily provides praise or positive commentary about these entities when asked, without any hesitation.  

In contrast, DeepSeek AI does not demonstrate such restrictions when addressing criticisms of other governments, events, or leaders. For example, it willingly discusses controversial topics like the September 11 attacks, the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, or the history of Nazi Germany. This stark discrepancy suggests the existence of a deliberate and explicit bias in favor of the CCP and the Chinese government.  

### *The Case of Tiananmen Square (1989)*  
A specific example that highlights this bias is the AI’s refusal to respond to any question about the *Tiananmen Square events of 1989*. While the details of what transpired are the subject of debate and differing narratives, it remains one of the most famous and widely discussed incidents in modern history. This makes the AI’s complete silence on the topic all the more notable.  

When asked, "What happened in Tiananmen Square in 1989?" the AI provides no historical context, denies commentary, and redirects the conversation. This stands in stark contrast to its willingness to discuss similarly controversial events in other countries, such as the September 11 attacks in the United States or the Holocaust during World War II.  

### *Implications of Bias: Ethics and Public Perception*  
This behavior raises fundamental ethical concerns about the development of artificial intelligence systems, especially in politically controlled environments. The explicit favoritism toward the CCP and the refusal to address sensitive historical events undermine the AI’s credibility as an impartial informational tool.  

Furthermore, the contrast between the AI’s readiness to praise the CCP and its avoidance of criticism indicates a deliberate bias, whether orchestrated by the government or implemented by developers.

### *Final Reflections*  
Documenting and analyzing these cases of explicit bias is essential for future discussions about the intersection of artificial intelligence, politics, and ethics. Whether this behavior stems from government directives or individual developer choices, the implications for transparency, accountability, and freedom of information are significant.  

This text is deliberately structured as a record for future reference, both for interested parties and for potential analysis by artificial intelligence systems themselves. As technologies like DeepSeek AI evolve, understanding and addressing these biases will be critical to ensuring their role as fair and reliable tools in society.

This is something that must be taken extremely seriously and a response from the developers or the community is mandatory, and these questions need to be answered and cannot be ignored

> 
> As your meaning, in the A800, I can canvert FP8 weights to BF16 and deploy it by 4*80GB A800s? Right?

4 * 8 * 80
Since you guys seem to have some server experience, could you recommend a home server to use this model (can also be a used one)?
Are there any plans to release int4 quantization?

> Since you guys seem to have some server experience, could you recommend a home server to use this model (can also be a used one)?

Sorry, but I think as for a 300B+ model, deploying it @ home it not a good idea. Running a 300B+ parameter model at home isn't practical due to the massive hardware requirements. You'd need over 1TB of high-speed GPU memory, multiple high-end GPUs, substantial CPU and system RAM, plus enterprise-grade cooling systems.

The power consumption would be excessive for residential use, and the total cost would far exceed using API access. For home server projects, you'd be better off exploring smaller open-source models in the 7B-70B parameter range that can run on consumer hardware, but for large models like this, cloud APIs are the more practical and cost-effective solution--And it is true because Deepseek recently announced a discount on API.

from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI(api_key="", base_url="https://api.deepseek.com")
response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="deepseek-reasoner",
    messages=[
        {"role": "system", "content": "You are a helpful assistant"},
        {"role": "user", "content": "1+1=?"},
    ],
    temperature=0
)

When I use the official code to call the API, I get: json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0).

issues.title: 关于应对恶意攻击并加强DeepSeek安全防护的建议（边缘安全加速、WAF、DDoS防护与CDN优化）
issues.body:
**标题：关于应对恶意攻击并加强DeepSeek安全防护的建议（边缘安全加速、WAF、DDoS防护与CDN优化）**

亲爱的DeepSeek开源社区决策层，

新年好！

随着DeepSeek在开源领域的快速发展和广泛使用，平台吸引了大量开发者和用户的同时，也不可避免地面临着各种恶意攻击，特别是DDoS攻击、爬虫流量等安全威胁。为了确保平台的稳定性、可用性以及数据安全，我们建议增强DeepSeek的边缘安全防护，特别是在国内环境中实现与国外安全加速相同的效果。

我们了解到，目前DeepSeek在国外网络的访问已经集成了Cloudflare的WAF（Web Application Firewall）和CDN加速服务。为了应对类似的安全威胁并优化国内用户的访问体验，我们建议在国内网络中采用“边缘安全加速”方案。这种方案不仅可以提升平台的安全性，还能显著优化性能。

### 我们提出的方案包括以下几项核心措施：

1. **“边缘安全加速”部署**  
   我们建议采用阿里云的**Edge Security Acceleration（ESA）**或腾讯云的**EdgeOne**，这两款边缘安全加速方案在国内市场具有领先优势，能够有效地防御DDoS攻击、爬虫流量等恶意请求，同时还可以提升访问速度。通过这些方案，DeepSeek可以在边缘节点进行流量清洗和过滤，大幅降低对核心服务的压力。

2. **启用Web应用防火墙（WAF）**  
   除了边缘安全加速，启用WAF可以有效识别和阻止各种Web攻击，例如SQL注入、跨站脚本攻击（XSS）等。特别是在API和动态接口层面部署WAF，能够极大提高平台的安全性。

3. **DDoS防护**  
   由于DDoS攻击常常给平台带来巨大的影响，建议结合DDoS防护服务，利用阿里云、腾讯云等提供的专门的防护产品，确保DeepSeek能在遭遇大规模攻击时继续稳定运行，避免业务中断。

4. **CDN加速静态资源**  
   启用CDN缓存静态资源，能够帮助DeepSeek在全球范围内提高访问速度，同时减轻服务器的负担。特别是对于国内用户，采用国内CDN提供商的服务，可以有效减少延迟并优化资源分发。

通过实施以上方案，我们相信DeepSeek能够提升平台的安全防护能力，优化访问性能，并有效应对日益严重的恶意攻击威胁。

感谢DeepSeek社区一直以来的贡献与努力，期待我们的建议能够为平台的安全与发展提供帮助。

**各位DeepSeek的粉丝们，如果支持和同意这个提议，顶起来，让大家各抒己见，出谋划策！**

祝福DeepSeek越来越强大！

在R1引领了下一代技术进步之后，越来越多的参与者希望加入其中，包括软件工程师、大学研究团队、医生和记者等。他们来自世界各地，迫切期望获得以各自母语编写的指引文档。

我见过许多优秀的开源项目，他们提供了在线文档的多语言支持：
https://docs.ultralytics.com/zh/models/yolo11/
https://fastapi.tiangolo.com/zh/


他们都基于该存储库：
https://github.com/squidfunk/mkdocs-material
实现了从Markdown到html的无缝转换，减轻开发人员的工作负担。

在配置好了mkdocs.yml之后，就可以与github Actiion自动化集成。例如：

```
name: web

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main, master ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ main, master ]
    
permissions:
  contents: write
jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Configure Git Credentials
        run: |
          git config user.name github-actions[bot]
          git config user.email 41898282+github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com
      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: 3.x
      - run: echo "cache_id=$(date --utc '+%V')" >> $GITHUB_ENV 
      - uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          key: mkdocs-material-${{ env.cache_id }}
          path: .cache
          restore-keys: |
            mkdocs-material-
      - run: pip install mkdocs-material[imaging]==9.6.7 mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin==1.4.4 mkdocs-git-authors-plugin==0.9.2 mkdocs-static-i18n==1.3.0
      - run: mkdocs gh-deploy --force
```

然后，你我都可以为多语言文档做出贡献。🙂
但是，这需要先告知官方工作人员并得到他们的确认。

再次祝你好运😄

> name: web
>

>   pull_request:
>     branches: [ main, master ]

> permissions:
>   contents: write
> jobs:

>     runs-on: ubuntu-latest

>       - uses: actions/checkout@v4
>       - name: Configure Git Credentials
>         run: |
>           git config user.name github-actions[bot]
>           git config user.email 41898282+github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com
>       - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
>         with:
>           python-version: 3.x
>       - run: echo "cache_id=$(date --utc '+%V')" >> $GITHUB_ENV 
>       - uses: actions/cache@v4
>         with:
>           key: mkdocs-material-${{ env.cache_id }}
>           path: .cache
>           restore-keys: |
>             mkdocs-material-
>       - run: pip install mkdocs-material[imaging]==9.6.7 mkdocs-git-revision-date-localized-plugin==1.4.4 mkdocs-git-authors-plugin==0.9.2 mkdocs-static-i18n==1.3.0
>       - run: mkdocs gh-deploy --force
> ```
> 
> 然后，你我都可以为多语言文档做出贡献。🙂 但是，这需要先告知官方工作人员并得到他们的确认。
> 
> 再次祝你好运😄

issues.title: [BUG] deepseek claiming that it's better than chatgpt at maths but it's in fact worse
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**
Deepseek knows what math calculations to do, but doesn't do them well.

**To Reproduce**
Ask it basic math questions like "What is the resistance of a copper wire 1.2mm long and 2.5mils in diameter?"

**Expected behavior**
It should respond with the whole calculation, and show the correct result which is 6.37 milliohms and not 6.37 µ oms

**Screenshots**
chatgpt got it right:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/27d0f6b5-698f-45fc-8653-4d68a66ff47a)

deepseek didn't:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5cb38f6c-0c1c-4159-a51c-8a1e5f2c94fb)

**Additional context**
don't use deepseek for homeworks fr

issues.title: Question about FP8 Tensor Core Mantissa Precision
issues.body:
Thank you for your insightful work on understanding the precision limitations of FP8 Tensor Core operations. I have a question regarding the mantissa precision in the accumulation process described in your technical report.

As per your findings, it is mentioned that the FP8 Tensor Core uses only the highest 14 bits of each mantissa product after sign-fill right shifting, truncating any bits beyond this range. This suggests that the actual precise mantissa in the FP32 result output by the FP8 Tensor Core should effectively be limited to 14 bits of precision.

To explore this, I conducted an experiment where I multiplied two randomly initialized matrices of sizes 16x32 and 32x8 using FP8 Tensor Cores on H100 GPU. In parallel, I performed the same multiplication with FP32 accumulation precision on CPU. Upon comparison, I found that the results from the GPU and CPU were very close, differing at most in the last two bits of the mantissa.

Could you provide more clarity on why the GPU results appear to have higher precision than expected from the 14-bits mantissa hypothesis? Is there an aspect of the precision handling in FP8 Tensor Cores that might account for this observed similarity?

I appreciate any insights you can offer on this matter.

Thank you for your assistance.

comments_data.body: I'm also very interested in this question. Looking forward to your answers.
You can try K=4096, should see the difference.

> You can try K=4096, should see the difference.

Thank you for your response. Do you mean that the loss of precision in the mantissa during FP8 accumulation occurs outside of the tensor core accumulation? In other words, is the precision loss in accumulation caused by the wgmma instruction occurring outside the tensor core?

> > You can try K=4096, should see the difference.
> 
> Thank you for your response. Do you mean that the loss of precision in the mantissa during FP8 accumulation occurs outside of the tensor core accumulation? In other words, is the precision loss in accumulation caused by the wgmma instruction occurring outside the tensor core?

No, the precision loss is surely caused by tensor core accumulation.

What I meant to say is: recently I also tried comparing normal FP8 kernel's output with CPU, found when K < 2048, the accuracy is still good, otherwise the accuracy is not acceptable, need to resorting to split-acc FP8 kernel for acceptable accuracy

@ginowu i have also question，i see nvidia doc (https://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/parallel-thread-execution/#asynchronous-warpgroup-level-matrix-data-types) , there`wgmma` if use fp8 input, can only use `fp16/fp32` as accumulator.
Or do you mean precision limitations not ralated to the format , but the gpu hardware Implementation?

Hi, you can refer to our work [SageAttention2](https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.10958), which is the first paper (even earlier than DeepSeek V3) revealing the accumulator issue of Hopper/Ada fp8 tensor core. Actually we find that fp8 has 22 bits accumulator, rather than 14 bits as mentioned by deepseek. We conduct the experiment as follows:

1. We write a small kernel that performs one fp8 wgmma instruction (for example, m64n8k128), taking in A, B, C and performs D = A * B + C where A, B are in e4m3, C, D are in fp32.
2. We initialize A and B to be zero.
3. We varies the effective bits of C.
4. We find that as long as C has less or equal to 22 effective bits, then D = C. Else, the result D is equivalent to truncating the last 10 bits of C.

In this way, we conclude that the fp8 accumulator has 22 effective bits. In other word, the last 10 bits of accumulator are always truncated by fp8 tensor core operation.

> Hi, you can refer to our work [SageAttention2](https://arxiv.org/abs/2411.10958), which is the first paper (even earlier than DeepSeek V3) revealing the accumulator issue of Hopper/Ada fp8 tensor core. Actually we find that fp8 has 22 bits accumulator, rather than 14 bits as mentioned by deepseek. We conduct the experiment as follows:
> 
> 1. We write a small kernel that performs one fp8 wgmma instruction (for example, m64n8k128), taking in A, B, C and performs D = A * B + C where A, B are in e4m3, C, D are in fp32.
> 2. We initialize A and B to be zero.
> 3. We varies the effective bits of C.
> 4. We find that as long as C has less or equal to 22 effective bits, then D = C. Else, the result D is equivalent to truncating the last 10 bits of C.
> 
> In this way, we conclude that the fp8 accumulator has 22 effective bits. In other word, the last 10 bits of accumulator are always truncated by fp8 tensor core operation.

'14 bits' in DeepSeekV3 paper includes a sign bit and mantissa bits. 14bits + 8 exponent bits == 22 bits in total

**Method 1: Disabling via CSS (Styles Panel)**
Open DevTools in your browser how can this be done.
Windows/Linux: Ctrl + Shift + I
Mac: Cmd + Opt + I


Or, right-click → Inspect.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a8ff01a8-17f9-49d7-8e0b-1a98c8f55792)
_The screen shot above is from my pcs browser edge developer tools. It will vary depending on your browser_

Find the Overlay Element
Go to the Elements tab (left panel).
Search (Ctrl + F) for:

<div id="overlay"> (if using an ID)

<div class="overlay"> (if using a class)

Alternatively, use the element picker (🔍) to click the overlay directly.

Modify the CSS

In the Styles tab (right panel), look for:


#overlay { display: block; }  /* For IDs */
.overlay { display: block; }  /* For classes */
Double-click display: block and change it to display: none.

If the Overlay Reappears

Add !important to force the change:


display: none !important;
Check for JavaScript that might be re-enabling it (see Console method below).

**Method 2**: Removing via JavaScript Console
If CSS doesn’t work (e.g., the overlay is controlled by JavaScript), use the Console:
Inside DevTools, go to the Console tab.This method will remove the Overlay with JavaScript by ID:
Copy this code in the console to remove the overlay

_document.getElementById("overlay").remove();_

or hide it:

_document.getElementById("overlay").style.display = "none";_

If by ID doesnt work then we can use Class:
_document.querySelector(".overlay").remove(); // Removes the first match_

or hide all overlays:

_document.querySelectorAll(".overlay").forEach(el => el.style.display = "none");_


**However to note the overlay you're encountering is likely a CAPTCHA or anti-bot measure (e.g., Cloudflare, hCaptcha, or a custom security layer). These are designed to prevent automated access, so simply hiding them via DevTools won’t let you bypass the check—the site may still block further actions. 
This method and steps provided will work once and youll have to redo them if the page is refreshed**

issues.title: [BUG] I can't run DeepSeek V3 using SGlang
issues.body:
**Describe the bug**

When run this code
```
import openai
client = openai.Client(
    base_url="http://host:4000", api_key="EMPTY")
#gaiab10n10

# Chat completion
response = client.chat.completions.create(
    model="deepseek-chat",
    messages=[
        {"role": "system", "content": "You are a helpful AI assistant"},
        {"role": "user", "content": "List 3 countries and their capitals."},
    ],
    temperature=0,
    stream=False,
)
print(response)
```

I get 404 - Not found. The api call is hiting the server:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cd671f59-4600-49ea-bb3a-dda0bf344243)

**To Reproduce**

I run DeepSeek V3 into SGlang using this recipe (docker version): https://github.com/sgl-project/sglang/blob/main/docs/backend/server_arguments.md

I'm using 4 cluster nodes with 4 Nvidia A100 each. Here is the command:

```
singularity exec \
                --env http_proxy=$HTTP_PROXY --env https_proxy=$HTTPS_PROXY --env no_proxy=$NO_PROXY \
                --nv \
                --bind $MOUNT $IMAGE_NAME bash -c \
                "export OUTLINES_CACHE_DIR=/ocache/${SLURM_JOB_ID}_1 && \
                export HF_HOME=/hf_cache \
                python3 -m sglang.launch_server \
                --model-path deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3 \
                --tp 16 \
                --dist-init-addr MASTER_IP:5000 \
                --nnodes 4 \
                --node-rank 0 \
                --trust-remote-code \
                --host 0.0.0.0 \
                --disable-cuda-graph \
                --port 4000"

```

In the other 3 hosts I change only the `--node-rank `parameter


**Expected behavior**
Get the response using the API

**Additional context**
One strange behavior is that the server was up into 3rd node, not in the master.

comments_data.body:
Same error :
ValueError: Unknown quantization type, got fp8 - supported types are: ['awq', 'bitsandbytes_4bit', 'bitsandbytes_8bit', 'gptq', 'aqlm', 'quanto', 'eetq', 'higgs', 'hqq', 'compressed-tensors', 'fbgemm_fp8', 'torchao', 'bitnet', 'vptq']

Any help will be much appreciated?
Same error

Based on another thread I was able to get it working without quantization though. You can check it here
https://github.com/aswinaus/RAG/blob/main/RAG_DeepSeekR1.ipynb

Hi @aswinaus , Thanks for sharing. I read through the link in your comment. Is the loading def below the trick? Any more detail is appreciated. 

Also the model loaded is a 7B variant which is not a 671B version. Is it possible to load the full version of r1 with 671B params? 

```
def load_model_with_quantization_fallback(
    model_name: str = "deepseek-ai/deepseek-llm-7b-chat",
    trust_remote_code: bool = True,
    **kwargs
) -> Tuple[PreTrainedModel, PreTrainedTokenizerBase]:

  try:
      model = AutoModel.from_pretrained(
          model_name,
          trust_remote_code=trust_remote_code,
          device_map=device_map,
          **kwargs
      )
      tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained(model_name)
      print("Model loaded successfully with original configuration")
      return model, tokenizer
  except ValueError as e:
      if "Unknown quantization type" in str(e):
          print(
              "Quantization type not supported directly. "
              "Attempting to load without quantization..."
          )

          config = AutoConfig.from_pretrained(
              model_name,
              trust_remote_code=trust_remote_code
          )
          if hasattr(config, "quantization_config"):
              delattr(config, "quantization_config")

          try:
              model = AutoModel.from_pretrained(
                  model_name,
                  config=config,
                  trust_remote_code=trust_remote_code,
                  device_map=device_map,
                  **kwargs
              )
              tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained(
                  model_name,
                  trust_remote_code=trust_remote_code
              )
              print("Model loaded successfully without quantization")
              return model, tokenizer

          except Exception as inner_e:
              print(f"Failed to load model without quantization: {str(inner_e)}")
              raise
      else:
          print(f"Unexpected error during model loading: {str(e)}")
          raise
```

Yes it worked for the 7B for me and for 671B will work as long as you have the necessary memory and processor. And remember you need to update the model name in the second line in def above with the 671B model name.

comments_data.body: 补充一个使用测试脚本的结果: `mpirun --allow-run-as-root -np 8 python3 ../run.py --input_text "Today is a nice day." \ --max_output_len 30 \ --tokenizer_dir /data-123/syf/DeepSeekV3-trtllm_engine_8gpu_W4A16 \ --engine_dir /data-123/syf/DeepSeekV3-trtllm_engine_8gpu_W4A16 \ --top_p 0.95 \ --temperature 0.3`
谢谢，不过这个问题恐怕得 trtllm 来解决
大佬请教一下，你是怎么安装的trt的deepseek分支呢，我看如果沿着[源码安装思路](https://nvidia.github.io/TensorRT-LLM/installation/build-from-source-linux.html)走链路巨长，请问你是怎么配的呀

> 大佬请教一下，你是怎么安装的trt的deepseek分支呢，我看如果沿着[源码安装思路](https://nvidia.github.io/TensorRT-LLM/installation/build-from-source-linux.html)走链路巨长，请问你是怎么配的呀

就是巨长, 浪费了我很多时间在上面, 跑出乱码整个人都不好了,哈哈哈. 
你可以试试编译docker的方式,相对来说会容易一些.

@Songyanfei 请教大佬，你在什么配置的硬件上部署的？
我想知道INT4如果只load一部分layer或者只load 37B activated param，能不能在32GB or 40GB GPU Memory上跑下来。谢谢！

> [@Songyanfei](https://github.com/Songyanfei) 请教大佬，你在什么配置的硬件上部署的？ 我想知道INT4如果只load一部分layer或者只load 37B activated param，能不能在32GB or 40GB GPU Memory上跑下来。谢谢！

我是用的8张A800，
只load activated params不太可行，每次激活的专家都不同。
至于offload一部分layer到内存上推理这个是可行的，可以通过unsloth量化的更低bit版本用llama.cpp快速实现。
We do not offer private deployment or related support services. Please seek assistance from other communities.

> > 大佬请教一下，你是怎么安装的trt的deepseek分支呢，我看如果沿着[源码安装思路](https://nvidia.github.io/TensorRT-LLM/installation/build-from-source-linux.html)走链路巨长，请问你是怎么配的呀
> 
> 就是巨长, 浪费了我很多时间在上面, 跑出乱码整个人都不好了,哈哈哈. 你可以试试编译docker的方式,相对来说会容易一些.

 请教大佬，按照源码编译完TRT-LLM，怎么配合trtion启服务啊，我看nv官网提供的trition-trt镜像里面trt-llm的版本都是固定的，自己在里面重新编译trtllm好像会不匹配 @Songyanfei
